description.narrative: This project is one of the initiatives to boost peace in Darfur using Livelihoods as a crucial peace engine and a major connector, which aims at improving livelihood and local economic recovery.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of vulnerable households supported with assets to start productive activities disaggregated by value chain commodity and gender. 1.2 Percentage increase in agricultural production per household disaggregated by gender. 1.3 Number of Voluntary Savings and Loan Associations that are functional disaggregated by % of women and men participating. 1.4 Percentage of targeted households whose livelihood assets have increased in 36 months from project inception by gender. 1.5 Percentage increase in household 1.6 Percentage of beneficiaries reporting decrease in humanitarian aid and increased reliance on own resources by gender;

comment.narrative:
1.1.1 Total of 9,443 households (52%F) have been supported during the reporting period as follows: ▪ The Project has established three strategic partnerships with private sector entities, DARFOOD, DALFOOD and Nesta. Over 600 households have benefitted from the partnership, involving groundnuts, sesame, and livestock value chains. ▪ The Project is working with Nesta, the Innovation Challenge Centre in the United Kingdom, on diary innovation in South Darfur to identify innovative technologies to support production, processing, storage/preservation of dairy in Ed Elfursan. The design of the challenge has been completed, and it will be launched by the third quarter of 2021. ▪ 34 Producer Associations were established in East Darfur, South Darfur, and Central Darfur, with 1,700 members, including 52 per cent women. The Producer Associations are involved in livestock rearing, groundnuts, sesame, sorghum, dairy and honey production, processing and marketing. The groups have been registered and trained on group dynamics, group management, and processing and marketing. • The Project supported 1,350 households in 5 Darfur states involving 8,100 individuals with 20 tuk-tuks, 50 carts and 20 post-harvest equipment, including plastic sacks and sheet for harvesting, packaging and storage. • 290 people in South, North and East Darfur received a one-week training on value addition and quality control techniques on targeted value chains. • Also, some 40 women representatives received support on handicraft and food processing. • 80 vulnerable women from Abu Jabra and Abukarinka received cash transfer support • 350 households from Beida and Geneina localities were supported with various productive assets, including grinding machine, solar charging systems. 1.1.2 63 women-headed households were supported to restock their livestock in Tura locality in North Darfur. 1.1.3 42 Voluntary Savings and Loans Associations have been established in East Darfur, South Darfur, and Central Darfur with a total membership of 2,100 of which 80 percent are women. 1.1.4 This target will be measured at the end of the year through a survey 1.1.5 Indicator Not Measured: Assessment is being conducted. The indicator will be reported in the next report. 1.1.6 A survey is being conducted and the indicator will be reported on in the next report. Meanwhile, almost 100% of vulnerable beneficiaries have indicated increase in income and other assets which is an indication of increased self-reliance.
2.1.1 Fourteen (14) key productive and community infrastructure projects are being implemented benefiting over 60,000 individuals (comprising about 10,000 households). The construction of some of these assets started during the previous reporting period. See details below: • One (1) Health Vaccination Centre equipped with a refrigerator powered by a solar system in Tura. • one (1) water yard has been provided in Hilela community in the Dare Salam locality. • One (1) water yard in Taufaya in the Mellit locality. • Two (2) water handpumps rehabilitated in Tura, North Darfur • One (1) warehouse has been constructed to support 11 Groundnut Associations in Alait. • One (1) warehouse has been constructed in Malam Alwidian; • One (1) warehouse has been constructed in Kalimendo in North. • One warehouse has been rehabilitated in Daresalam town in North Darfur. • Two (2) warehouse is being constructed in East Darfur. • The Project constructed a solar-powered livelihoods hub equipped with furniture in Kalimendo, in North Darfur. • One (1) Community Center in Taufaya has been completed. • Two (2) livelihood hubs are being constructed in East Darfur in Dar El Salam Village in Karinka locality and Higliga village in Edaen locality. • One (1) livelihood hub is being constructed in South Darfur in Jogana in the Gereida locality. • Four (4) community joint farms were established/fenced with local materials and one farm with an irrigation system was established in Ed Elfursan. • Five (5) management committees were established 3 livelihoods hubs committees and 2 warehouse Committees with total members 75 (50M/25F). The Project will establish Joint Management Committees for the communal infrastructure established. 2.2.1 t is estimated that the completion of these 14 infrastructures will benefit over 30,000 households in different ways, including access to water for humans, livestock, and irrigation and other off and non-farm income generation opportunities. The community centres will also benefit all community members in terms of training and other community activities. The Collection centres will improve market access and reduce post-harvest losses and market access and reduce post-harvest losses. 2.3.1 Some 3,000 vulnerable women and youth (55% female) were employed in a temporary labour-intensive scheme to construct the above infrastructure, which increased their monthly incomes by 70% during the period. 2.3.2 Some other 200 people (63% female) were engaged voluntarily to rehabilitate some of the infrastructures. 2.4 To be measured at the end of year through perception surveys. 2.5 To be measured at the end of year through perception surveys.
3.1.1 The Project established/reactivated 25 PDCs in South Darfur, East Darfur, and Central Darfur benefiting over 35,000 people. The PDCs have been supported with basic stationeries and connected to the local justice and rule of law apparatus. 3.1.2 In addition, 10 Farm Protection Committees (FPCs) have been established, trained, and linked to the PDCs. 3.2 To be reported at the end of the year after perfection surveys are conducted. Meanwhile, the establishment of 6 PDCs have already contributed to access to these mechanisms. 3.3 To be reported at the end of the year after perfection surveys are conducted. 3.4 Monitoring processes are on-going in the target localities. So far, only 3 cases have been reported by the new PDCs of which 100% have been resolved.
4.1 UNDP partnered with the University of El Fasher Centre for Peace and Development Studies to assess the capacity of key institutions related to durable solutions and recovery. As a result, 5 key training workshops have been planned on ICT, leadership, community mobilization, arbitration, planning, monitoring, and evaluation across the 5 states of Darfur. UNDP provided computer equipment to four institutions in North Darfur and two institutions in each remaining Darfur states; South, East, Central, and West Darfur. 4.2 Trainings activities just started activities yet to be organized. Meanwhile, other related capacity building activities have been completed. 4.3 This indicator will be measured after all training has been completed and skills being put to use. 4.4 No field days and exchange visits were organized during this reporting report. More will be reported during the next reporting period
5.1 During the reporting period, up to 80% of the project staff are in place. Remaining staff required to maintain full capacity are being recruited. 5.2 During the reporting period 2 key field monitoring activities were carried out. However, during March, access to project locations was precluded by restrictions on movement. 5.3 Project risk log is being updated regularly. The key new risk that threatens the project is the COVID-19 which is likely to cause significant delays in the implementation process. Contingency measures are being put in place to mitigate risks. 5.4 One Project Board meeting was organized in February 2020

Workplan is under formulation (Draft targets will be under): 1. Support economic recovery in Darfur through reviving productive capacities and market access for most vulnerable groups, . including women, youth and IDPs 2. Strengthen Livelihoods for Peace and Recovery in Darfur (L4P) to enhance the resilience of conflict-affected communities by improving livelihoods and economic recovery as key drivers of peace and social cohesion
N/A as the project has started its activities in November 2019.

1.1 5000 vulnerable households supported with assets to start productive activities dis-aggregated by value chain commodity, gender(55% female) 1.2 50% agricultural production per household dis-aggregated by gender((50% female) 1.3 20 Voluntary Savings and Loans Associations that are functional disaggregated by % of women and men participating(55% Female). 1.4 80% of targeted households whose livelihood assets have increased 36 months from project inception by gender(80% female). 1.5 80% of increase in household annual income recorded by producer groups attributable to project activities by value chain by gender; (80% female) 1.6 At least 25% of Beneficiaries reporting decrease in humanitarian need and increased reliance on own resources by gender
2.1 10 infrastructures rehabilitated/ developed (by type) 2.2 5000 of households benefiting from infrastructure rehabilitated/ developed by age and gender((55% female). 2.3 1,000 of vulnerable men and women employed in temporary labor-intensive schemes by gender(55%F). 2.4 75% of community members stating an increase in access to critical basic services and community productive assets by gender; (80% Female). 2.5 75% of reduction in the distance to access critical infrastructure (e.g. water sources, grinding mills, TV, recreational center etc) (75% Female).
3.1 20 of Peace and Development Committees (PDCs) that are functional dis-aggregated by % of female membership(40% F). 3.2 95% of community members reporting increased access to dispute resolution mechanisms by gender; (95% Female). 3.3 98% of community members reporting decrease in natural resource related conflicts; by gender (55% Female) 3.4 95% of natural resource conflicts successfully mediated (95% female).
4.1 3 training workshops organized for Government and partner Civil Society Staff; 4.2 20 of Staff trained in selected technical areas dis-aggregated by type and gender (40% Female) 4.3 75% of supported Staff reporting increase in key skills and confidence in doing their jobs compared to those not supported by gender (80% Female) . 4.4 Five field days and exchange visits conducted;
5.1 12 technical experts and administrative support staff available 5.2 Quarterly project results tracked and reported 5.3 Quarterly project Risks are identified, tracked and managed proactively 5.4 Quarterly and Annually engagement with stakeholders.
